conclusion: Understanding the circuit with a battery, two resistors, two capacitors, and a switch.
Battery with E = 10V, resistors R1 = 4.0 ohms, R2 = 6.0 ohms, capacitors C1 = C2 = 30 microfarads, switch S initially closed.
When the switch is closed, current flows through R1 and R2, and capacitors charge up.
When the switch is opened, the path through R2 is broken, capacitors discharge through R1.
Resistors R1 and R2 are in series, total resistance is R1 + R2 = 10 ohms.
Current from the battery is I = E / (R1 + R2) = 1 A.
Capacitors charge through R1 and R2, C1 in parallel with R1, C2 in parallel with R2.
Voltage across R1 is 4 V, voltage across R2 is 6 V.
Capacitors C1 and C2 charge to 4 V and 6 V, respectively.
When switch is opened, C2 is connected directly to R1, in parallel with it.
C1 is still in parallel with R1.
C2 is effectively in parallel with C1 and R1.
Equivalent capacitance is C1 + C2 = 60 Î¼F.
